Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story:
I stood in the kitchen, the scent of cleaning spray lingering in the air as I wiped down the counters for the third time. My spouse’s voice echoed from the living room, reminding me that the relatives would arrive in just a few hours. Every surface had to shine, every cushion fluffed, every detail perfect. We had promised to share the work, but the list seemed endless, and my partner was counting on me to help make our home welcoming.

Yet, my mind kept drifting to the letter from the travel agency, the one confirming my spot for Hajj. The doctor’s words replayed in my head: “If you want to go, this is your chance. Next year might be too late.” The weight of this once-in-a-lifetime obligation pressed on my heart. I felt torn—my faith urging me to seize this sacred opportunity, my spouse needing me here, now, to fulfill our shared responsibilities. My hands scrubbed, but my thoughts wrestled, caught between the demands of devotion and the expectations of love.
